note.title: The Origin of SQLite, the Worldâ€™s Most Widely-Used Database

pageProps.body:
The Origin of SQLite, the Worldâ€™s Most Widely-Used Database

https://thenewstack.io/the-origin-story-of-sqlite-the-worlds-most-widely-used-database-software/

Two decades ago, while building software for a Navy destroyer, he led the creation of a new open source database to overcome the glitches he encountered. Then Google came calling.

Jul 11th, 2021 6:00am by David Cassel

Last week Adam Gordon Bell brought a special guest onto his podcast Corecursive: Richard Hipp, the main author of SQLite.

In a little more than two decades, itâ€™s become the most widely deployed database in the world, according to the official webpage at SQLite.org â€” partly due to its simplicity. Because itâ€™s contained in a library of C code, SQLite can be easily embedded into other software, and itâ€™s fully self-contained. â€œUnlike most other SQL databases, SQLite does not have a separate server process,â€ its official page explains. â€œSQLite reads and writes directly to ordinary disk files.â€

But crucially, itâ€™s also open source, which leads Bellâ€™s podcast to an intriguing question: What happens if your fun side project ends up powering the world? And the host promises that, along the way, the interview will explore the dilemma which still haunts the open source movement today: How to survive becoming core infrastructure for the world.

Bell points out that SQLite is now installed in everything from web browsers to commercial airplanes, as well as popular software like iMessage and WhatsApp.

But the software was born out of Hippâ€™s frustration with a database that was installed on a battleship.

â€˜Canâ€™t Connect to Serverâ€™

The story begins in a shipyard in Bath, Maine (population: 8,329). Back in the year 2000, Hipp was working for Bath Iron Works, a shipbuilding subsidiary of defense contractor General Dynamics, and was building software for a Navy destroyer (the USS Oscar Austin). The software would operate on crucial data about the shipâ€™s valves (for routing around pipe ruptures), and their stack had included Informix, which unfortunately stopped working whenever the server went down.

â€œThat was embarrassing,â€ Hipp recalled to Bell. â€œA dialog box would pop up, theyâ€™d double click on the thing, and a dialog box would pop up that says, â€˜Canâ€™t connect to database server.â€™ It wasnâ€™t our fault â€” we didnâ€™t have any control over the database server. But what do you do if you canâ€™t connect to the server? So we got the blame all the same, because we were painting the dialog box.â€

And, as Hipp noted, â€œitâ€™s a warship.â€ So besides the ship being continually in use, â€œthe idea is itâ€™s supposed to be able to work if you take battle damage! So itâ€™s more than one pipe breaking. Thereâ€™s going to be a lot of stuff broken, and people are going to be crazy, and thereâ€™s going to be smoke and blood and chaos â€” and in a situation like that they donâ€™t want a dialog box that says, â€˜Cannot connect to database server.'â€

Hipp wondered if there was a way his team could pull its data straight from the database without an external dependency. â€œI looked around and there were no SQL database engines that would do that, and one of the guys I was working with says, â€˜Richard, why donâ€™t you just write one?'â€ During a temporary shutdown of government contracts (which had lasted a few months), â€œI was out of work for a few months, and I thought, â€˜Well, Iâ€™ll just write that database engine now.'â€

Back in 2006, Hipp tried to explain SQLiteâ€™s appeal to an audience at Google. â€œMost people hear SQL database engine, and theyâ€™re thinking Oracle â€” something big that you run your whole enterprise on. SQLite is sort of the opposite of that â€” it tries to be very small, so itâ€™s very compact.â€ In fact, fully configured, at the time it was less than 250 kilobytes. And it was also serverless â€” and designed to be embedded within larger applications.

But the story of SQLite also shows how initiative and dedication can pay off â€” and how nothing can stop a determined developer. Later in his interview at Corecursive.com, Hipp recalled looking for a reference on how to write an SQL database engine â€” and not finding one.

â€œSo I just had to kind of invent it myself,â€ he said. â€œIt was a completely independent invention.â€

For instance, Hipp remembers referring to Donald Knuthâ€™s The Art of Computer Programming for an implementation of a search algorithm. While theoretical underpinnings mightâ€™ve been taught at MIT, Harvard, or the University of California-Berkeley, â€œif you didnâ€™t go to one of those three schools, you didnâ€™t even know this body of theory existed, and there wasnâ€™t a real good way to find it.â€

Years later he learned that nonetheless, both SQLite and Postgres had converged on the same ideas.

Ironically, back at the shipyard, Hippâ€™s higher-ups still insisted on usingÂ  Informix, Hipp tells Bell (although his team did use SQLite for their testing). But in addition, â€œI put it out there on the internet and other people started picking it up.â€ Soon Hipp was surprised by the uptake â€” including one user whoâ€™d bragged they now had an SQL database engine running on their Palm Pilot. â€œIt really attracted a lot of attention, and that encouraged me to work on it.â€

Ringing Phones

Hippâ€™s website still proudly points out that SQLite won a 2005 Google Oâ€™Reilly Open Source Award. But that was the only acclaim that SQLite received. Back in 2006, Hipp told his audience at Google that â€œitâ€™s public domain, so lots of people are using it that I donâ€™t know aboutâ€ â€” but confirmed users included Apple and PHP. (At one point both General Electric and Toshiba had contacted him requesting the U.S. export control number for SQLite â€” though he never found out why.)

But soon Hipp confronted another theme that haunts most open source developers: monetization. Hipp told the Corecurisve podcast that very early on, heâ€™d received a phone call from Motorola, whoâ€™d wanted to include SQLite in its operating system for cellphones. â€œOf course, inside, I was like, â€˜What? You can make money with open source software? How does this work? How do I price this?â€ Hipp said. â€œI have no idea how to do this.'â€

But fortuitously, heâ€™d brought in three people whoâ€™d worked on the original SQLite, â€œand that was sort of the beginning.â€

The next call he fielded was from America Online, which wanted to use an SQLite database on the free-trial CDs it was sending in the mail to prospective users. And soon there was a call from Symbian (which made the operating system on Nokia phones). The company had tested 10 different database systems â€” two open source, and seven more proprietary. But even after giving the other vendors a chance to fine-tune their systems, SQLite still won the competition. Hipp recalled, â€œWe cut a contract to do some development work for them.â€

This led to an important development, when Symbian asked them to increase their â€œbus factor,â€ which Hipp describes as â€œthe number of people who have to be hit by a bus in order to stop all development workâ€¦ They felt like the bus factor at SQLite was too low.â€ Symbianâ€™s solution? It helped fund the SQLite Consortium, which Hipp said is â€œa way of funding the project and getting more people involved to guarantee that it was going to be available long term.â€

But he also gives a lot of credit to Mitchell Baker (pictured), who was then the CEO of the Mozilla Foundation (and a lawyer by training). Sheâ€™d reached out, and as he remembers it, insisted that â€œthe developers have to be in control. Their decision is finalâ€¦ The companies that are using, they get the honor of contributing money, but you make all the decisions. She was very adamant about this and she laid out everything.â€

In the end, Mozilla and Adobe joined Symbian in funding the group, and to this day Hipp expresses gratitude for all the early support. â€œitâ€™s been such an amazing journeyâ€¦ we would not be in this situation were it not for these circumstances.

When Google Calls

Soon all major smartphones were using SQLite, Adam explains â€” and soon Richard fielded a phone call from Google, â€œbefore Android was a thing. This was before iPhone.â€

This led the project to another key open source lesson about the value of testing. â€œItâ€™s amazing how many bugs will crop up when your software suddenly gets shipped on millions of devices,â€ Hipp told Bell.

He spent a whole year generating tests to cover every single branch operation in the resulting binary code, he said. Heâ€™d had hopes of selling the test suite to avionics manufacturers â€” but while they never landed any customers, when it came to reports of bugs in Android, â€œit made a huge, huge difference. We just didnâ€™t really have any bugs for the next eight or nine years.â€

As a result, he said, â€œIt did work out really well for us in that it keeps our product really solid and it enables us to turn around new features and new bug fixes very fast.â€

The details are pretty impressive. â€œWeâ€™ll have a test case but itâ€™ll be parameterized, so that one test case might run 100, 1,000, 100,000 tests, just by looping, by changing one of the parameters.â€ For a typical release, Hipp estimated that thereâ€™s on the order of 100,000 distinct test cases â€” and billions of tests. â€œWe have a checklist and we will run tests for at least three days prior to a release.â€

Corecursiveâ€™s interview closed with Hippâ€™s own inspiring advice to others who want to create impactful open source software. â€œI had this crazy idea that Iâ€™m going to build a database engine that does not have a server, that talks directly to disk, and ignores the data types,â€ he said. â€œAnd if you asked any of the experts of the day, they wouldâ€™ve said, â€˜Thatâ€™s impossible. That will never work. Thatâ€™s a stupid idea.â€™

Fortunately, I didnâ€™t know any experts â€” and so I did it anyway.â€

  - boredom -> easy fun -> art -> profit?

> I've often described my motivation for building software to others using imagery: I like to go find a secluded beach, build a large, magnificent sand castle, and then walk away. Will anyone notice? Probably not. Will the waves eventually destroy it? Yep. Did I still get immense satisfaction? Absolutely. - [aliasxneo](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=41497113)

> We love to see the process, not just the result. The imperfections in your work can be beautiful if they show your struggle for perfection, not a lack of care. - [ralphammer](https://ralphammer.com/is-perfection-boring/)

> Simplicity, even if it sacrifices some ideal functionality has better survival characteristics than the-right-thing. - [The Rise of Worse is Better](https://www.dreamsongs.com/RiseOfWorseIsBetter.html)

> [Roberto Blake was talking about making 100 crappy videos](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OnUBaQ1Sp_E) to get better over time. Putting in the reps and improving a little bit each time.
>
> Putting in the work without expecting any external reward at first (eg views, followers, likes, etc) will pay off in the long run. - [100 Scrappy Things](https://www.florin-pop.com/blog/100-scrappy-things/)

> Make the difficult habitual, the habitual easy, and the easy beautiful. - [Constantin S. Stanislavski](https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/7102271-make-the-difficult-habitual-the-habitual-easy-and-the-easy)

> A good match is a **structured** dance, where players aim to **score** while they are following well-defined **rules**. This **freedom within a structure** is what makes it fun. - [ralphammer](https://ralphammer.com/how-to-get-started/)

- [Pivot Points](https://longform.asmartbear.com/pivot-points/)

  - non-judgmental aspects of personality that can be strengths in some contexts and weaknesses in others
  - Pivot Points are fixed in the short term

- [Hedged Bets](https://longform.asmartbear.com/predict-the-future/#hedged-bets)
  - trading slightly less maximum upside for predictable, net-positive outcomes.

> â€œMotivation often comes after starting, not before. Action produces momentum.â€
> [When you start a new habit, it should take less than two minutes to do.](https://jamesclear.com/how-to-stop-procrastinating)
>
> - James Clear

> Focus is more about **not** keeping busy when you need to wait for something.  
> Eat the boredom for a minute.
>
> - [[life-tips#wodenokoto]]

> [4 minutes run hard enough to push heart rate to 90%, 3 minutes recover, repeat 4 times](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=34213181)
>
> - https://www.ntnu.edu/cerg/advice
> - [Get running with Couch to 5K](https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/exercise/running-and-aerobic-exercises/get-running-with-couch-to-5k/)

> [recommended routine - bodyweightfitness](https://www.reddit.com/r/bodyweightfitness/wiki/kb/recommended_routine/) - I Don't Have This Much Time!
>
> - Don't workout at all (saves anywhere from 20 to 60 minutes, but really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really not recommended)

> I think it should be everyone's primary focus to sleep well, drink water, get outside, get active, and eat generally decently. I hate to say it, but if you're not eating a good amount of vegetables and fruit, decent protein, sleep, etc, no amount of XYZ will catch up to that detriment. - [CE02](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=35056071)

> My real battle is doing good versus doing nothing. - [Deirdre Sullivan](https://www.npr.org/2005/08/08/4785079/always-go-to-the-funeral)

[Kind Engineering](https://kind.engineering/) - How To Engineer Kindness

> Sometimes magic is just someone spending more time on something than anyone else might reasonably expect. - [Teller](https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/6641527-sometimes-magic-is-just-someone-spending-more-time-on-something)
